results.title: Blood money
results.creator_credit: Tom Broadbridge, Chris Oliver and Chris Fitchett
results.brief_description: Tense thriller starring Bryan Brown and John Flaus. Pete, a professional criminal who is dying of cancer, returns to Melbourne to settle a few scores. He wants to meet up with his ex-girlfriend and effect a reconciliation before facing death. The crime story is presented entirely from the criminal’s perspective. Rated: M

results.title: Blood is life
results.creator_credit: Basic Films and Great Britain. Ministry of Health
results.brief_description: Illustrates the work of Britain’s National Blood Transfusion Service. Shows how highly-trained personnel safeguard the health of donors and patients, by scrupulous care of equipment and checking of records. Describes the care with which blood is classified and stored, and how it finally reaches the patient in the operating theatre.

results.title: Blood can work miracles
results.brief_description: An appeal to all in normal health between 18 and 65 to act as regular blood donors, instancing ways in which blood is used to save life, in accident surgery, open heart surgery, using the heart-lung machine, for mother or baby in childbirth emergencies, and in the treatment of anaemias and of burns. Donor sessions are shown to be quite friendly occasions, and the giving of blood painless and without after-effect.

Donor sessions are shown to be quite friendly occasions, and the giving of blood painless and without after-effect.

results.title: Blood and water
results.brief_description:
A thought-provoking short film set in the future. Australia’s water has run out - as a result the government has restricted acces to water, issuing citizens with one container of water every three days. Civil unrest has broken out and the military has imposed martial law. This is the story of a father who must protect his daughter at all costs in a society where survival is paramount. Cast includes Tim Ferris, Pepita Emmerichs, Jeremy Kewley. Shot mainly in black and white with some color sequences.
Written and directed by Nicholas Carlton, produced by William Hardie.

results.title: Blood and flowers: in search of the Aztecs
results.creator_credit: BBC, Learning Channel, Time-Life Films and Liz Gray
results.brief_description: This story of one of the world’s most intriguing ancient civilizations - the Aztecs - begins in the 14th century in the Valley of Mexico. The Aztecs were a highly evolved society, literate, cultural and amazingly adaptable to what was a fairly inhospitable environment. They were able to transform the landscape to suit their needs and to build their temples and houses. But they were also a civilization consumed with mythological beliefs inextricably linked to nature and the seasons and these beliefs required offerings and sacrifices to the Gods, human sacrifices, to ensure the continuation of life. However their fate was not sealed by the Gods, but by the conquering Spanish Conquistadors 200 years later. This historical portrayal is told through re-enactments; ancient drawings, stoneworks, sculptures and architecture; computer animation; and interviews with Carlos Fuentas (Writer), David Carrasco (Historian of Religions), Richard Townsend (Art historian), and others including archaeologists and academics. Also contains some spectacular photographic footage of many of the sacred sites, including the remains of the Great Pyramids and the ancient cities of Tenochtitlan and Teotihuaca, along with images of Mexico City as it is today - the old world and the new world living side by side as the Aztec legacy continues on. Presented by Dr Tony Spawforth.

results.title: Blood and circulation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanics of Life”.
Uses x-ray photography and animation to describe how the human blood system is designed. Shows the composition of blood through microphotography, and discusses the role of each blood component.

results.title: Blood and ash
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts and Emma Freeman
results.brief_description: Set in late 19th century outback Australia, this richly textured, contemplative short drama traces a young woman’s journey, both literal and metaphorical, into unknown terrain after the death of her mother. On her journey to find the river where she wants to scatter her mother’s ashes, Tilda (Maya Stange), grieving and vulnerable, becomes lost in the bush, where she undergoes a series of transformative encounters. Engaging with visual and thematic styles associated with the Western genre, the film employs archetypal motifs to make connections between the individual and the landscape. Cast also includes Rachel Maza, David Tredinnick and Suzy Cato.

results.title: Blood-borne pathogens in the workplace
results.brief_description: Blood-borne pathogens are microorganisms which can cause disease. They can be found in infected blood and bodily fluids. Diseases which can be spread by blood-borne pathogens include malaria and syphilis, but today, the most common are Hepatitis B and AIDS. This program gives clear, practical information on what blood-borne pathogens are, how they can (and can’t) be transmitted, what you can do to reduce the risk of transmission in the workplace, and how to minimise risk if you are exposed to a blood-borne pathogen due to an accident. Made with the support of the Infection Control Department, Fairfield Hospital.
